channel.title: The End of the Universe
channel.description:
The question popped up when I was talking to my sis's boyfriend about stuff like the 4th dimension, evolution, the origin of the universe, etc. Is there really and end to the universe, where the meaning of end being a boundary or something? The universe surely can't have an end, but then again it can't go on forever. And if there's an end, where's the beginning of the universe. Certain ideologies come into play here, i.e. the 4th dimension,time travel, and other things.
Discuss now...

item.title: The End of the Universe
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

First, if you were talking to your sisters boyfriend about that, I’d say you and your sister’s boyfriend need to take a step outside and see the world.

Second, I quote from the other “OMG WORLD IS ENDING” topic.

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:23, topic:175671”]No. Global warming is a myth, the Earth is heating up, but the Earth goes in 10 year cycles. One decade will be rainy, next will be sweltering drought. Look up the temperatures for that last 10 and the 10 before that

The world is not going to end, for a while.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: The End of the Universe
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

[quote=“goatee, post:25, topic:175172”][quote author=ThatOneServer link=topic=235691.msg2013795#msg2013795 date=1201291562]

I think Global Warming is an incorrect phrase. It gets extremely cold, and extremely hot here in Canada. More of a difference every year. It mostly gets very very cold.

Climate change is correct imo. The balance of weather gets more and more unbalanced.

Consistant with polar shifts
[/quote]

Has any well known climatology expert said that it’s polar shifts? Cos i think that’s a load of shit.[/quote]
Nope, but geologists have.
Climatology just means that the planet is getting warmer, which is true. There should be a reason.

It being our fault is just bullshit.

Read full topic

item.title: The End of the Universe
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

The universe cannot end i think. Its just nothingness. If you go far out enough, there will probably be no celestial bodies at all. No stars, planets, dust, anything like that. Then itll just go on for infinity.

Read full topic

The question popped up when I was talking to my sis’s boyfriend about stuff like the 4th dimension, evolution, the origin of the universe, etc. Is there really and end to the universe, where the meaning of end being a boundary or something? The universe surely can’t have an end, but then again it can’t go on forever. And if there’s an end, where’s the beginning of the universe. item.title: The End of the Universe
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

Chimaera God:

Along with my first question, does anyone believe that there are other “intelligent” life forms in the universe besides humans. There has to be, because what are the chances that we are the only life forms that can contemplate our place in the universe? To add, where did we even come from, how did all life originate on Earth in the first place? How did everything of known existence begin? Where did that object the size of an atom that supposedly created the universe come from?

It’s stupid to think there is not. Lets say for a moment that the chance of there being life on any one given planet is 1 in one octillion, which is an incredibly slim chance. It’s still far fetched to even entertain the idea of there not being life on other planets.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

The answer is so simple. If it’s the end you seek, you’ll find it if you go far enough. Otherwise, the universe is without end.

Read full topic

item.title: The End of the Universe
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

As gravity pulls all the stars, gas clouds, etc together, eventually it will form a superdense “blob” of matter. This blob will become so dense that it eventually implodes, releasing all the matter back out for the universe to form again. (Hint: big bang).

Read full topic

item.title: The End of the Universe
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Define the universe.

An expanding body made up of galaxies, or a container for everything else to live in?

If the first, who’s to say it dosen’t end, and something else lies outside it?

Read full topic

I’d answer the rest but they hurt my head.
There was a topic created recently about the beginning of life forms on earth, search it up.

Read full topic

item.title: The End of the Universe
item.dc:creator: @Chimaera_God Chimaera God
item.description:
@Chimaera_God wrote:

[quote=“Zach1188, post:3, topic:175172”]As humans, in the 3rd dimension, our brains cannot comprehend infinity, thus we assume there must be an ending. There is not, there is no end; space, time, and probability do go on forever, in their respective “directions”.

We cannot comprehend these “directions” (or higher dimensions), as, obviously, they do not exist in the 3rd dimension. So they cannot be defined by length, width, or height, so in our dimension, they are only theoretical. Therefore, it’s impossible to prove we exist.[/quote]

That’s the point I was trying to make to my sis’s boyfriend last night; he said that there had to be limits to everything because of certain laws like physic and such. The thing is, these laws that are used to explain what we (humans) have found can’t place limits, or any kind of restriction upon anything in the known universe for that matter because the basis that they’re set on can’t really be explained.

Along with my first question, does anyone believe that there are other “intelligent” life forms in the universe besides humans. There has to be, because what are the chances that we are the only life forms that can contemplate our place in the universe? To add, where did we even come from, how did all life originate on Earth in the first place? How did everything of known existence begin? Where did that object the size of an atom that supposedly created the universe come from?

Most of these question will most likely never have an answer, but I wanted to see what the people on this forum had in thought.

Read full topic

item.title: The End of the Universe
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

Oh i thought he ment like the beginning and end, not space-wise.

It isn’t really possible to define an end if you say theres more than one universe.

Parellel universes could be the answer, which then a end could be defined

Read full topic
